\documentclass[../main.tex]{subfiles}

\begin{document}

We will freely use the results of \Cref{graded_stuff} in this section. In what follows, fix an $A$-graded ring $R$. Further suppose that for all $a,b\in A$, there exists units $\theta_{a,b}\in R_0$ such that:\begin{itemize}
	\item For all $a\in A$, $\theta_{a,0}=\theta_{0,a}=1$,
 	\item For all $a,b\in A$, $\theta_{a,b}^{-1}=\theta_{b,a}$,
  	\item For all $a,b,c\in A$, $\theta_{a,b}\cdot\theta_{a,c}=\theta_{a,b+c}$ and $\theta_{b,a}\cdot\theta_{c,a}=\theta_{b+c,a}$. %https://q.uiver.app/#
	\item For all $x\in R_a$ and $y\in R_b$,
	\[x\cdot y=y\cdot x\cdot\theta_{a,b}.\]
\end{itemize}

\begin{definition}
	Let $\GrCAlg R$ denote the following category:\begin{itemize}
		\item The objects are pairs $(S,\varphi)$ where $S$ is an $A$-graded ring and $\varphi:R\to S$ is an $A$-graded ring homomorphism such that for all $x\in S_a$ and $y\in S_b$, we have
		\[x\cdot y=y\cdot x\cdot\varphi(\theta_{a,b}),\]
		\item The morphisms $(S,\varphi)\to(S',\varphi')$ are $A$-graded ring homomorphisms $f:S\to S'$ such that $f\circ\varphi=\varphi'$.
	\end{itemize}
\end{definition}

\begin{lemma}\label{objects_in_R-GrCAlg_are_R-bimodules}
	Let $(S,\varphi)$ be an object in $\GrCAlg R$. Then $S$ is canonically an $A$-graded $R$-bimodule via the action maps $(r,s)\mapsto\varphi(r)\cdot s$ and $(s,r)\mapsto s\cdot\varphi(r)$ for $r\in R$ and $s\in S$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	\todo{TODO}
\end{proof}

\begin{proposition}
	Let $(B,\varphi_B)$ and $(C,\varphi_C)$ in $\GrCAlg R$. Then since $B$ and $C$ are $A$-graded $R$-bimodules (\autoref{objects_in_R-GrCAlg_are_R-bimodules}), their $R$-tensor product $B\otimes_RC$ is also an $A$-graded $R$-bimodule (\autoref{A-graded_module}). Then $B\otimes_RC$ is canonically an element of $\GrCAlg R$, with product
	\[(B\otimes_RC)\times(B\otimes_RC)\to(B\otimes_RC)\]
	sending pure homogeneous tensors $(b\otimes c,b'\otimes c')$ to the element
	\[\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot(bb'\otimes cc'),\]
	(where here $\cdot$ denotes the left module action of $R$ on $B\otimes_RC$), and with structure map
	\begin{align*}
		\varphi:R&\to B\otimes_R C \\
		r&\mapsto \varphi_B(r)\otimes 1_C.
	\end{align*}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
	First we claim the indicated map is well-defined and actually gives $B\otimes_RC$ the structure of an $A$-graded ring. Here we are employing \autoref{A_graded_ring}, so it suffices to check the map is well-defined, unital, associative, and distributive with respect to homogeneous elements. By distributivity, it further suffices to check this for pure homogeneous tensors. First, to see that this product is well-defined and distributive, it suffices to check that for all homogeneous $b\in B$ and $c\in C$ that the assignments $B\times C\to B\otimes_RC$
	\[(b',c')\mapsto (b\otimes c)(b'\otimes c')=\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot(bb'\otimes cc')\qquad\text{and}\qquad (b',c')\mapsto(b'\otimes c')(b\otimes c)=\theta_{|c'|,|b|}\cdot(b'b\otimes c'c)\]
	are $R$-balanced, as then we get that the product $(B\otimes_RC)\times(B\otimes_RC)\to B\otimes_RC$ is an $A$-graded homomorphism of abelian groups in each argument, as desired. We show that the first assignment is $R$-balanced, showing the second is entirely analagous. To see this, note that given $b,b',b''\in B$, $c,c',c''\in C$, and $r\in R$ homogeneous with $|b'|=|b''|$ and $|c'|=|c''|$, that
	\begin{align*}
		(b\otimes c)((b'+b'')\otimes c')&=\theta_{|c|,|b'+b''|}\cdot((b(b'+b''))\otimes cc') \\
		&=\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot(bb'\otimes cc')+\theta_{|c|,|b''|}\cdot(bb''\otimes cc') \\
		&=(b\otimes c)(b'\otimes c')+(b\otimes c)(b''\otimes c'),
	\end{align*}
	where in the second equality we are using that $|b'+b''|=|b'|=|b''|$,
	\begin{align*}
		(b\otimes c)(b'\otimes(c'+c''))&=\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot(bb'\otimes c(c'+c'')) \\
		&=\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot(bb'\otimes c c')+\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot(bb'\otimes c c'') \\
		&=(b\otimes c)(b'\otimes c')+(b\otimes c)(b'\otimes c''),
	\end{align*}
	and
	\begin{align*}
		(b\otimes c)(b'r\otimes c')&=\theta_{|c|,|b'r|}(bb'r\otimes cc') \\
		&\overset{(1)}=\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot\theta_{|c|,|r|}\cdot(bb'\otimes rcc') \\
		&\overset{(2)}=\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot\theta_{|c|,|r|}\cdot(bb'\otimes cr\varphi_C(\theta_{|r|,|c|})c') \\
		&\overset{(3)}=\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot\theta_{|c|,|r|}\cdot(bb'\otimes\varphi_C(\theta_{|r|,|c|})crc') \\
		&\overset{(4)}=\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot\theta_{|c|,|r|}\cdot(bb'\varphi_B(\theta_{|r|,|c|})\otimes crc') \\
		&\overset{(3)}=\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot\theta_{|c|,|r|}\cdot(\varphi_B(\theta_{|r|,|c|})bb'\otimes crc') \\
		&\overset{(5)}=\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot\theta_{|c|,|r|}\cdot\theta_{|r|,|c|}\cdot(bb'\otimes crc') \\
		&\overset{(6)}=\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot(bb'\otimes crc') \\
		&=(b\otimes c)(b'\otimes rc'),
	\end{align*}
	where:\begin{itemize}
		\item $(1)$ follows by the fact that $|b'r|=|b'|+|r|$, by definition, so that $\theta_{|c|,|b'r|}=\theta_{|c|,|b'|+|r|}=\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot\theta_{|c|,|r|}$,
		\item $(2)$ follows by the fact that since $(C,\varphi_C)$ is an object in $\GrCAlg{R}$ that $rcc'=cr\varphi_C(\theta_{|r|,|c|})c'$,
		\item Each occurrence of $(3)$ follows by the fact that since $\theta_{|r|,|c|}$ is of degree $0$, it commutes with everything, since $\theta_{|r|,|c|}\cdot x=x\cdot\theta_{|r|,|c|}\cdot\theta_{0,x}=x\cdot\theta_{|r|,|c|}\cdot1=x\cdot\theta_{|r|,|c|}$,
		\item $(4)$ follows by definition of the tensor product,
		\item $(5)$ follows by definition of the $R$-bimodule structure on $B\otimes_RC$, and
		\item $(6)$ follows by the fact that $\theta_{|c|,|r|}^{-1}=\theta_{|r|,|c|}$.
	\end{itemize}

	Now, to see this product is associative, let $b,b',b''\in B$ and $c,c',c''\in C$ homogeneous. Then
	\begin{align*}
		((b\otimes c)(b'\otimes c'))(b''\otimes c'')&=(\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot (bb'\otimes cc'))(b''\otimes c'') \\
		&=\theta_{|cc'|,|b''|}\cdot\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot (bb'b''\otimes cc'c'') \\
		&\overset{(1)}=\theta_{|c|,|b''|}\cdot\theta_{|c'|,|b''|}\cdot\theta_{|c|,|b'|}\cdot(bb'b''\otimes cc'c'') \\
		&\overset{(2)}=\theta_{|c|,|b''|+|b'|}\cdot\theta_{|c'|,|b''|}\cdot(bb'b''\otimes cc'c'') \\
		&=(b\otimes c)(\theta_{|c'|,|b''|}(b'b''\otimes c'c'')) \\
		&=(b\otimes c)((b'\otimes c')(b''\otimes c'')),
	\end{align*}
	as desired.
\end{proof}

\begin{definition}
	An \emph{$R$-ring} is a monoid object (\autoref{monoid_object}) in the category of $A$-graded $R$-bimodules. An \emph{$R$-coring} is a monoid object in the opposite category of the category of $A$-graded $R$-bimodules.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}
	A \emph{right $R$-bialgebroid $B$} consists of an $R$-bimodule $B$ with the structure of an $R\otimes R^\op$-ring $(B,s,t)$ and an $R$-coring $(B,\Delta,\vare)$ such that:\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*)]
		\item The bimodule structure in the $R$-coring $(B,\Delta,\vare)$ is related to the $R\otimes R^\op$ ring $(B,s,t)$ via
		\[r\cdot b\cdot r'=b\cdot s(r')\cdot t(r),\qquad\text{for $r,r'\in R$, $b\in B$}.\]
	\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}
	A \emph{Hopf algebroid}
\end{definition}

\end{document}
